item.title: Navigating a Mid-Career Tech Stack Shift - Engineering Manager AMA
item.description:
You want to switch tech stacks, but you're panicking. All of that hard work goes completely down the drain. You start back at square one as a junior developer.
... Or do you? Let's discuss!
As with all livestreams, I'm looking forward to answering YOUR questions! So join me live and ask in the chat, or you can comment now and I can try to get it answered while I stream.

item.title: Building a CoAP application on Ariel OS
item.description: Ariel OS is an embedded operating system written in Rust, whose first version 0.1. was released recently. It is designed for "constrained devices" (a.k.a. "embedded devices" or "IoT devices"), that is, electronic devices with little power and storage ‚Äì think "what is in your remote control" and not "what is on your computer". The Constrained Application Protocol (CoAP) is a networking protocol for the same group of devices. It is similar to HTTP in its semantics, but tuned to simple implementation and small messages that work over the most low-power networks.

item.title: Rushing Toward Rewrite | RoseSecurity Development Log
item.description: This is part three of my microblog series exploring the subtle dysfunctions that plague engineering organizations. After discussing over-abstraction as a liability and unpacking how excessive toil kills engineering teams, this post tackles a nuanced threat: when ‚Äúmoving fast‚Äù becomes a cultural shortcut for cutting corners.

item.title: Finalizers are tricker than you might think. Part 2
item.description: In the previous part we discussed why the finalizers should only deal with unmanaged resources and in this post I want to show that this is not as simple as it sounds.

item.title: Spade | Spade Hardware Description Language
item.description: Spade is a new hardware description language which makes hardware description easier and less error-prone. It does this by taking lessons from software programming languages, and adding language level support for common hardware constructs, all without compromising low level control over what hardware gets generated.
